properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow on Wednesday. Location: western and northern Nova Scotia. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and then begin to taper off in the afternoon in the west and evening in the north. Current indications suggest total snowfall of 10 cm but more is possible. Snowfall warnings may be expanded westward in future updates. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:27:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:28:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1121616019.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected today. Lake effect snow squalls are expected to develop in a west flow off Lake Superior around midday today. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible along with significant reductions to visibility under the most intense bands. Snow squall activity will shift southward tonight as winds become northerly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T00:39:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T08:40:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1843103553.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm conditions likely Wednesday night and Thursday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm (10 to 20 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday night), north to northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Some areas in northeastern Newfoundland may see a brief change over to rain or drizzle overnight on Wednesday night before changing back to snow again on Thursday. Strong winds will combine with falling snow to reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially in the northeast on Thursday. Conditions will improve in the south and central by mid day on Thursday, but will continue in the west and northeast until Thursday evening. At this time, the Great Northern Peninsula may receive the least amount of snow, with potentially less snow than mentioned above. However, a shift in the track could bring those heavier amounts further north. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:31:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:32:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0809919158.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More snow and wind expected Wednesday night and Thursday. Possible total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm (5 to 10 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Possible wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday evening), southwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (overnight Wednesday night), northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday afternoon). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Precipitation will change over to rain or drizzle by Wednesday evening with some minor rainfall amounts possible. Precipitation will change back to snow again overnight Wednesday night before continuing into the day on Thursday. Any significant blowing snow will likely only occur Thursday afternoon after the snow redevelops and the temperatures fall below freezing. Conditions will improve in the south Thursday morning, but will linger in the east until Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:31:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:32:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0700250145.2020

properties.Summary:

Snow will change to a few rain showers this afternoon as warmer air moves into the area. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. A Pacific frontal system will transit across southern B.C. today bringing snow, heavy at times. Further snowfall amounts for today will be 10 to 15 cm. Snow is forecast to change to rain this afternoon for areas closer to the U.S. border as a milder southerly flow develops. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific weather system is expected to bring heavy snow to the Icefields Parkway, Highway 93, beginning late this afternoon. Snowfall totals are expected to be around 20 cm before the snow tapers off on Wednesday afternoon. Blowing snow in open areas is also expected to create snow drifts over the highway. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values of minus 50 or colder will persist over the next day. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on Wednesday. Locations: central and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to central and eastern parts of the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and persist into the evening. Current indications suggest that total snowfall of 10 cm is likely however more is still possible. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A moist Pacific frontal system is bringing rain to the South Coast of BC. Heavy rain started last night. The heavy rain will continue this morning and finally ease late this afternoon as the storm system leaves the region. Total rainfall accumulations of 60 to 90 mm are expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy on Wednesday. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Location: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and then begin to taper off in the evening over mainland Nova Scotia and overnight in Cape Breton. Current indications suggest total snowfall of 15 to 25 cm. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Higher than normal water levels are expected at high tide Wednesday afternoon or evening along the Cape Breton coastline and the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:30:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:31:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0876888763.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A Pacific weather system is expected to bring 10 to 15 cm of snow beginning this afternoon, to portions of west central Alberta, and spreading eastward towards the Edmonton area though the overnight hours. The snow is expected to taper off Wednesday afternoon. Snowfall warnings may need to be expanded towards the Saskatchewan border as the system develops. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T03:31:42-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will track across southern B.C. today. Heavy snow will continue today and tonight giving 30 to 50 cm. Total accumulations near 70 cm is likely by Wednesday morning. Snow will ease Wednesday morning as the system exits the province. ### Rapidly accumulating snow and drifting snow will make travel very difficult. Poor weather conditions are likely to contribute to long-lasting transportation delays. Expect road closures as avalanches are possible. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
